item.title: Chapter 08 - Section 01
item.description:
Exercises

Ex. 11

For $f_n(x) = \frac{\displaystyle{x}}{\displaystyle{x+n}}$, and $f = 0$, Clearly

$||f_n - f ||_{[0,a]} = ||f_n||_{[0,a]} = \frac{\displaystyle{a}}{\displaystyle{a+n}}$. But $\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\displaystyle{a}}{\displaystyle{a+n}} = 0$. Hence by lemma 8.1.8 (page 244), The uniform convergence on $[0,a]$ follows.

We follow Lemma 8.1.5 (page 244). Consider subsequences $n_k = x_k = k$. Then $f_{n_k}(x_k) = \frac{\displaystyle{k + k}}{\displaystyle{k}} = \frac{\displaystyle{1}}{\displaystyle{2}}$. Therefore $|f_{n_k}(x_k) - f(x_k)| = |f_{n_k}(x_k)| = \frac{\displaystyle{1}}{\displaystyle{2}} = \epsilon_0$.

item.title: Chapter 10 - Section 01
item.description:
Exercises

1

a

By definition of a gauge, we have \begin{aligned} t_i - \delta(t_i) &\leq x_{i-1} \\ x_i &\leq t_i + \delta(t_i) \end{aligned} Implying, \begin{aligned} x_i - x_{i-1} \leq t_i + \delta(t_i) - x_{i-1} \\ -t_i + \delta(t_i) \geq -x_{i-1} \end{aligned} Concluding for all $i \in \{ 1,2, \dots, n \}$, \begin{aligned} x_i - x_{i-1} &\leq t_i + \delta(t_i) - t_i + \delta(t_i) \\ &\leq 2 \delta(t_i) \end{aligned}

b

Clearly $x_i - x_{i-1} \leq 2 \delta^*$ for all $i \in \{1, 2, \dots, n\}$. Then $\max \\{x_i - x_{i-1}\\} = ||\dot{p}|| \leq 2 \delta^*$.
